spokesperson said that Duterte welcomed a proposed Congressional investigation into extrajudicial killings to be chaired by Senator [[Leila de Lima]], his chief critic in the government. On August 17, Duterte announced that de Lima had been having an affair with a married man, her driver, Ronnie Palisoc Dayan. Duterte claimed that Dayan was her collector for drug money, who had also himself been using drugs.{{Cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/807597/duterte-tells-de-lima-i-have-witnesses-against-you|title=Duterte tells De Lima: I have witnesses against you|last=Señase|first=Charlie C.|date=August 18, 2016|work=Inquirer Mindanao, Philippine Daily Inquirer|access-date=22 August 2016|archive-url=https://archive.today/20160818125518/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/807597/duterte-tells-de-lima-i-have-witnesses-against-you|archive-date=August 18, 2016|dead-url=yes|publisher=Inquirer.net|df=}} In a news conference on August 21, Duterte announced that he had in his possession [[wiretap]]s and [[Cash machine|ATM]] records which confirmed his allegations. He stated: "What is really crucial here is that because of her [romantic] relationship with her driver which I termed 'immoral' because the driver has a family and wife, that connection gave rise to the corruption of what was happening inside the national penitentiary." Dismissing fears for Dayan's safety, he added, "As the President, I got this information … as a privilege. But I am not required to prove it in court. That is somebody else's business. My job is to protect public interest. She's lying through her teeth." He explained that he had acquired the new evidence from an unnamed foreign country.{{cite news|title=‘Love affair led to corruption’|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/love-affair-led-to-corruption/281280/|accessdate=22 August 2016|agency=The Manila Times|issue=August 21, 2016|publisher=LLANESCA PANTI}} On August 18, [[United Nations]] human rights experts called on the Philippines to halt extrajudicial killings. [[Agnes Callamard]], the UN Special Rapporteur on summary executions, stated that Duterte had given a "license to kill" to his citizens by encouraging them to kill.{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=54707#.V7r8N5h942w|title=UN rights experts urge Philippines to end wave of extrajudicial killings amid major drug crackdown|last=|first=|date=August 18, 2016|website=UN News Centre|publisher=United Nations|access-date=22 August 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=20388&LangID=E|title=UN experts urge the Philippines to stop unlawful killings of people suspected of drug-related offences|last=|first=|date=August 18, 2016|website=United Nations Human Rights Office of the High Commissioner|publisher=United Nations|access-date=22 August 2016}} In response, Duterte threatened to [[Withdrawal from the United Nations|withdraw from the UN]] and form a separate group with African nations and China. Presidential spokesperson [[Ernesto Abella]] later clarified that the Philippines was not leaving the UN.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/143822-philippines-not-leaving-un-amid-duterte-threat|title=Philippines 'not leaving' UN amid Duterte threat|last=Esmaquel|first=Paterno|date=22 August 2016|website=Rappler|publisher=|access-date=22 August 2016}} As the official death toll reached 1,800, a Congressional investigation of the killings chaired by de Lima was opened.{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/philippines-drug-war-deaths-double-president-duterte-lashes-out-u-n635686 |title=Philippines Drug-War Deaths Double as President Duterte Lashes Out at U.N.|publisher=''[[NBC News]]''|date=22 August 2016}} On August 23, [[Chito Gascon]], head of the Philippine [[Commission on Human Rights (Philippines)|Commission on Human Rights]], told the Senate committee that the [[International Criminal Court]] may have jurisdiction over the mass killings.{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/808902/chr-icc-may-exercise-jurisdiction-over-ph-drug-killings-if |title=CHR: ICC may exercise jurisdiction over PH drug killings if …|publisher=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]''|date=August 23, 2016}} On August 25, Duterte released a "drug matrix" supposedly linking government officials, including de Lima, with the [[New Bilibid Prison drug trafficking scandal]].{{cite news|title=Duterte matrix out; tags De Lima, ex-Pangasinan gov, others|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/809467/duterte-matrix-out-de-lima-ex-pangasinan-gov-in-bilibid-drug-trade|accessdate=August 25, 2016|date=August 25, 2016}} De Lima stated that the "drug matrix" was like something drawn by a 12-year-old child. She added, "I will not dignify any further this so-called 'drug matrix' which, any ordinary lawyer knows too well, properly belongs in the garbage can."{{cite news|title=Duterte's drug matrix|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/08/25/duterte-drug-matrix.html|accessdate=August 25, 2016|work=CNN Philippines|date=August 25, 2016}}{{cite news|title=De Lima laughs off Duterte's 'drug matrix'|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/578884/news/nation/de-lima-laughs-off-duterte-s-drug-matrix|accessdate=August 25, 2016|work=GMA News|date=August 25, 2016}} On August 29, Duterte called on de Lima to resign and "hang herself".{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/144535-president-rodrigo-duterte-senator-leila-de-lima-resign-hang-yourself|title=Duterte to De Lima: Resign, hang yourself…|work=[[Rappler]]|date=29 August 2016}} ===State of emergency=== Following the [[2016 Davao City bombing|September 2 bombing in Davao City]] that killed 14 people in the city's central business district, on September 3, 2016, Duterte declared a "state of lawlessness", and on the following day signed a declaration of a "[[2016 state of emergency in the Philippines|state of national emergency]] on account of lawless violence in Mindanao".{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4479616/rodrigo-duterte-philippines-obama-davao-blast/ |title=Rodrigo Duterte declares a state of emergency in the Philippines |publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |author=Solomon, F. |date=September 6, 2016 |accessdate=September 6, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/145290-philippines-duterte-signs-state-national-emergency-lawless-violence-proclamation |title=Duterte signs state of nat'l emergency proclamation |publisher=[[Rappler]] |author=Ranada, P. |date=September 5, 2016 |accessdate=September 6, 2016}} The [[Armed Forces of the Philippines]] and the Philippine National Police were ordered to "suppress all forms of lawless violence in Mindanao" and to "prevent lawless violence from spreading and escalating elsewhere". Executive Secretary [[Salvador Medialdea]] said that the declaration "does not specify the imposition of curfews", and would remain in force indefinitely. He explained: "The recent incidents, the escape of terrorists from prisons, the beheadings, then eventually what happened in Davao. That was the basis."{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/09/06/1621023/palace-issues-proclamation-state-national-emergency |title=Palace issues proclamation of state of national emergency |publisher=[[The Philippine Star]] |author=Viray, P.L. |date=September 6, 2016 |accessdate=September 6, 2016}} The state of emergency has been seen as an attempt by Duterte to "enhance his already strong hold on power, and give him carte blanche to impose further measures" in the Drug War.{{cite news|title=Duterte’s First 100 Days|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/daniel-wagner/dutertes-first-100-days_b_12389874.html|accessdate=October 9, 2016|work=Huffington Post|date=October 7, 2016}} At the 2016 [[ASEAN Summit]], US President [[Barack Obama]] cancelled scheduled meetings with Duterte to discuss extrajudicial killings after Duterte referred to Obama as a "son of a whore".{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/09/05/philippine-president-threatens-to-curse-out-obama-obama-calls-him-a-colorful-guy/ |title=Obama cancels meeting with ‘colorful’ Philippine president, who now expresses regret…|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|date=September 5, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/09/05/politics/philippines-president-rodrigo-duterte-barack-obama/ |title=After cursing Obama, Duterte expresses regret…|publisher=''[[CNN]]''|date=September 5, 2016}} ===Senate committee=== On September 19, 2016, the Senate voted 16-4 to remove de Lima from her position heading the Senate committee, in a motion brought by senator and boxer [[Manny Pacquiao]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/146689-senate-ousts-leila-de-lima-justice-committee|title=Senate ousts De Lima as justice committee chairperson|work=Rappler|date=September 19, 2016}} Duterte's allies in the Senate argued that de Lima had damaged the country's reputation by allowing the testimony of [[Edgar Matobato]]. She was replaced by Senator [[Richard J. Gordon|Richard Gordon]], a supporter of Duterte.{{cite news |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/news/archive/2016/09/rodrigo-duterteleila-de-lima-investigation/500642/ |title=The Philippine President's Dwindling Opposition |work=The Atlantic |date=September 19, 2016 |accessdate=September 26, 2016 }} Matobato had testified that while working for the Davao Death Squad he had killed more than 50 people. He said that he had witnessed Duterte killing a government agent, and he had heard Duterte giving orders to carry out executions, including ordering the bombing of mosques as retaliation for an attack on a cathedral.{{cite news|title=Philippine hitman says he heard Duterte order killings|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-drugs-duterte/philippine-hitman-says-he-heard-duterte-order-killings-idUSKCN11L16K|accessdate=October 4, 2017|agency=Reuters|date=September 15, 2016}} Duterte told reporters that he wanted "a little extension of maybe another six months" in the Drug War, as there were so many drug offenders and criminals that he "cannot kill them all".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/19/philippine-president-rodrigo-duterte-extend-drug-war-kill-them-all|title=Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte to extend drug war as 'cannot kill them all'|work=The Guardian|date=September 19, 2016}}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/rodrigo-duterte-philippines-president-to-extend-war-on-drugs-because-he-cant-kill-them-all-a7318236.html |title=Rodrigo Duterte: Philippines president to extend war on drugs because he 'can't kill them all' |work=[[The Independent]] |date=September 20, 2016 |accessdate=September 28, 2016 }} On the following day, a convicted bank robber and two former prison officials testified that they had paid bribes to de Lima. She denies the allegations.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-drugs-idUSKCN11Q1H7 |title=Duterte critic took bribes, Philippine felons tell Congress members |work=Reuters |date=September 20, 2016 |accessdate=September 22, 2016 }} In a speech on September 20, Duterte promised to protect police in the Drug War: {{quote|For as long as I am the president, nobody but nobody – no military man or policeman will go to prison because they performed their duties. ... If [drug suspects] pull out a gun, kill them. If they don't, kill them, son of a whore so it's over, lest you lose the gun. I'll take care of you.{{cite news |title=Duterte to troops: Massacre criminals, I’ll promote you |url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/146890-duterte-troops-massacre-promotion |accessdate=October 19, 2018 |work=Rappler |date=September 21, 2016}}{{cite news |title=Ronald dela Rosa: 'The Rock' behind Duterte's drugs war |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-44598858 |accessdate=October 19, 2018 |publisher=BBC |date=June 27, 2018}}}} At a press conference on September 30, Duterte appeared to make a comparison between the Drug War and [[The Holocaust]].{{cite news|title=Philippines, Vietnam to create 6-year action plan for cooperation|url=http://www.rappler.com/world/regions/asia-pacific/147767-philippines-vietnam-six-year-plan-joint-statement|work=[[Rappler]]|author=Ranada, Pia}} He said that "[[Adolf Hitler|Hitler]] massacred three million Jews. Now there are three million drug addicts. I’d be happy to slaughter them."{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/147797-duterte-portrayed-hitler-cousin|title=Duterte: I'm being portrayed as a 'cousin of Hitler'|work=Rappler}} His remarks generated an international outcry. [[United States Secretary of Defense]] [[Ash Carter]] said the statement was "deeply troubling".{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/147860-pentagon-chief-reaction-duterte-hitler-remarks|title=Duterte's Hitler remarks 'troubling' – Pentagon chief|work=Rappler}}{{cite news|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/145909/dutertes-hitler-remarks-deeply-troubling-says-pentagon-chief|title=Duterte’s Hitler remarks ‘deeply troubling,’ says Pentagon chief|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer}} The German government told the Philippine ambassador that Duterte's remarks were "unacceptable."{{cite news|title=Germany: Duterte Hitler remarks ‘unacceptable’|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/145919/germany-duterte-hitler-remarks-unacceptable|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer}} On October 2, Duterte announced, "I apologize profoundly and deeply to the Jewish". He explained, "It's not really that I said something wrong but rather they don't really want you to tinker with the memory".{{cite news|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/583523/news/nation/duterte-apologizes-to-jews-for-hitler-remarks|title=Duterte apologizes to Jews for Hitler remarks|work=GMA News}}{{cite news|title=Duterte apologizes to Jews for Hitler remark|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/10/02/1629622/duterte-apologizes-jews-hitler-remark|work=The Philippine Star}} At the beginning of October, a senior police officer told ''[[The Guardian]]'' that 10 "special ops" official police death squads had been operating, each consisting of 15 police officers. The officer said that he had personally been involved in killing 87 suspects, and described how the corpses had their heads wrapped in masking tape with a cardboard placard labelling them as a drug offender so that the killing would not be investigated, or they were dumped at the roadside ("salvage" victims). The chairman of the Philippines Commission on Human Rights, [[Chito Gascon]], was quoted in the report: "I am not surprised, I have heard of this." The PNP declined to comment. The report stated: "although the ''Guardian'' can verify the policeman's rank and his service history, there is no independent, official confirmation for the allegations of state complicity and police coordination in mass murder."{{cite news|title=Philippines secret death squads: officer claims police teams behind wave of killings|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/04/philippines-secret-death-squads-police-officer-teams-behind-killings|accessdate=October 6, 2016|work=The Guardian}} On October 28, [[Datu Saudi Ampatuan]] Mayor Samsudin Dimaukom and nine others, including his five bodyguards, were killed during an anti-illegal drug operation in Makilala, [[North Cotabato]]. According to police, the group were heavily armed and opened fire on police, who found sachets of methamphetamine at the scene. No police were injured.{{cite news|title=End of the road for mayor on drug list, 9 others|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/835698/end-of-the-road-for-mayor-on-drug-list-9-others|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer}}{{cite news|title=Maguindanao mayor, 9 others dead in clash with anti-drug police|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/835160/at-least-10-dead-in-clash-between-police-maguindanao-mayors-group|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer}} Dimaukom was among the drug list named by Duterte on August 7; he had immediately surrendered, and then returned to Datu Saudi Ampatuan.{{cite news|title=8 Maguindanao officials linked to drugs surrender to PNP chief|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/803795/8-maguindanao-officials-allegedly-involved-in-drugs-surrender-to-pnp-chief|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer}} On November 1, it was reported that the [[US State Department]] had halted the sale of 26,000 [[assault rifles]] to the PNP after opposition from the [[Senate Foreign Relations Committee]] due to concerns about human rights violations. A police spokesman said they had not been informed. PNP chief [[Ronald dela Rosa]] suggested China as a possible alternative supplier.[http://www.cnn.com/2016/11/02/asia/philippines-us-arms-sale-reaction/index.html?eref=rss_topstories Philippines' Duterte: We'll turn to Russia if US won't sell us guns], [[CNN]]. November 2, 2016.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-usa-rifles-idUSKBN12V2AM Exclusive: U.S. stopped Philippines rifle sale that senator opposed - sources], [[Reuters]]. November 1, 2016. On November 7, Duterte reacted to the US decision to halt the sale by announcing that he was "ordering its cancellation".{{cite news|title=Duterte cancels order of 26,000 rifles from US|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/149121/duterte-cancels-order-of-26000-rifles-from-us|accessdate=November 8, 2016|work=Inquirer|date=November 7, 2016}} In the early morning of November 5, Mayor of [[Albuera, Leyte|Albuera]], [[Death of Rolando Espinosa|Rolando Espinosa Sr.]], who had been detained at Baybay City Sub-Provincial Jail for violation of the Comprehensive Dangerous Drugs Act of 2002, was killed in what was described as a shootout inside his jail cell with personnel from the Criminal Investigation and Detection Group (CIDG).{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/151353-albuera-mayor-rolando-espinosa-killed-jail|title=Albuera Mayor Espinosa killed in jail operation|work=Rappler}} According to the CIDG, Espinosa opened fire on police agents who were executing a search warrant for "illegal firearms."{{cite news|title='NANLABAN'? - With video: Albuera Mayor Espinosa killed in Leyte jail|url=http://www.interaksyon.com/article/133992/nanlaban--albuera-mayor-espinosa-killed-in-leyte-jail-cell|work=InterAksyon}} A hard drive of CCTV footage which may have recorded the shooting of Espinosa is missing, a provincial official said.{{cite news|title=CCTV footage of Albuera mayor's death missing|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/11/05/16/cctv-footage-of-albuera-mayors-death-missing|work=ABS-CBN News}} Espinosa had turned himself in to PNP after being named in Duterte's drug list in August.{{cite news|title=DUTERTE'S LIST: 'Narco' politicos, lawmen, judges|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/08/07/16/dutertes-list-narco-politicos-lawmen-judges|work=ABS-CBN News}}{{cite news|title=Albuera Mayor Espinosa, 1 other inmate killed in jail cell shootout – CIDG|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/regional/2016/11/05/Albuera-Mayor-Rolando-Espinosa-killed-in-jail.html|work=CNN Philippines}} He was briefly released but then re-arrested for alleged drug possession. The president of the National Union of People's Lawyers, Edre Olalia, told local broadcaster TV5 that the police version of events was "too contrived". He pointed out that a search warrant is not required to search a jail cell. "Such acts make a mockery of the law, taunt impunity and insult ordinary common sense." Espinosa was the second public official to be killed in the Drug War.{{cite news|title=Mayor accused over drugs killed in Philippines jail, say police|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/philippines-rodrigo-duterte-drugs-war-police-officers-kill-mayor-prison-a7399206.html|accessdate=November 7, 2016|work=The Independent|date=November 5, 2016}}{{cite news|title=Espinosa killing ‘incredibly brazen’ - rights lawyer|url=http://www.interaksyon.com/article/134001/espinosa-killing-incredibly-brazen---rights-lawyer|accessdate=November 7, 2016|work=InterAksyon|date=November 5, 2016}} Following the incident, on the same day, Senator [[Panfilo Lacson]] sought to resume the investigation of extrajudicial killings after it was suspended on October 3 by the Senate Committee on Justice and Human Rights.{{cite news|title=Lacson to seek resumption of Senate EJK probe after Espinosa’s killing|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/587639/news/nation/lacson-to-seek-resumption-of-senate-ejk-probe-after-espinosa-s-killing|work=GMA News}}{{cite news|title=Senate hearings on killings 'suspended until further notice'|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/583653/news/nation/senate-hearings-on-killings-suspended-until-further-notice|work=GMA News}} On November 28, Duterte appeared to threaten that human rights workers would be targeted: "The human rights [defenders] say I kill. If I say: 'Okay, I'll stop'. They [drug users] will multiply. When harvest time comes, there will be more of them who will die. Then I will include you among them because you let them multiply." Amnesty International Philippines stated that Duterte was "inciting hate towards anyone who expresses dissent on his war against drugs." The National Alliance against Killings Philippines stated: "His comment - that human rights is part of the drug problem and, as such, human rights advocates should be targeted too - can be interpreted as a declaration of an open season on human rights defenders".{{cite news|title=Duterte threat to kill rights defenders alarms groups|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/11/30/16/duterte-threat-to-kill-rights-defenders-alarms-groups|accessdate=December 3, 2016|work=ABSCBN|agency=AFP|date=November 30, 2016}} On December 5 Reuters reported that 97% of drug suspects shot by police died, far more than in other countries with drug-related violence. They also stated that police reports of killings are "remarkably similar", involving a "buy-bust" operation in which the suspect panics and shoots at the officers, who return fire, killing the suspect, and report finding a packet of white powder and a .38 caliber revolver, often with the serial number removed. {{quote|The figures pose a powerful challenge to the official narrative that the Philippines police are only killing drug suspects in self-defense. These statistics and other evidence amassed by Reuters point in the other direction: that police are pro-actively gunning down suspects.{{cite news|title=Police rack up an almost perfectly deadly record in Philippine drug war|url=https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/philippines-duterte-police/|accessdate=20 September 2017|agency=Reuters|date=December 5, 2016}}}} On December 8, the Senate Committee on Justice and Human Rights issued a report stating that there was "no evidence sufficient to prove that a Davao Death Squad exists", and "no proof that there is a state-sponsored policy to commit killings to eradicate illegal drugs in the country." Eleven senators signed the report, while senators Leila De Lima, JV Ejercito, Antonio Trillanes IV and Senate Minority Leader Ralph Recto did not sign the report or did not subscribe to its findings.{{cite web |url=http://interaksyon.com/article/135070/gordon-panel-no-proof-of-ejk-dds-in-war-on-drugs-under-duterte |date=December 8, 2016|accessdate=December 8, 2016|title= WATCH | Gordon panel: No proof of EJK, DDS in war on drugs under Duterte}} ===Temporary cessation of police drug operations=== Following criticism of the police over the [[kidnapping and killing of Jee Ick-Joo]], a [[South Korea]]n businessman, Duterte ordered the police to suspend drug-related operations while ordering the military and the Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency to continue drug operations. ===Amnesty International investigation=== On January 31, 2017, [[Amnesty International]] published a report of their investigation of 59 drug-related killings in 20 cities and towns, ''"If you are poor you are killed": Extrajudicial Executions in the Philippines' "War on Drugs"'', which "details how the police have systematically targeted mostly poor and defenceless people across the country while planting 'evidence', recruiting paid killers, stealing from the people they kill and fabricating official incident reports." They stated: "Amnesty International is deeply concerned that the deliberate, widespread and systematic killings of alleged drug offenders, which appear to be planned and organized by the authorities, may constitute crimes against humanity under international law."{{cite web|title=Philippines: The police's murderous war on the poor|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2017/01/philippines-the-police-murderous-war-on-the-poor/|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|accessdate=February 9, 2017}} A police officer with the rank of Senior Police Officer 1, a ten-year veteran of a [[Metro Manila]] anti-illegal drugs unit, told AI that police are paid 8,000 pesos (US $161) to 15,000 pesos (US $302) per "encounter" (the term used for extrajudicial executions disguised as legitimate operations); there is no payment for making arrests. He said that some police also receive a payment from the funeral home they send the corpses to. Hitmen hired by police are paid 5,000 pesos (US $100) for each drug user killed and 10,000 to 15,000 pesos (US $200–300) for each "drug pusher" killed, according to two hitmen interviewed by AI. {{quote|Family members and witnesses repeatedly contested the police description of how people were killed. Police descriptions bore striking similarities from incident to incident; official police reports in several cases documented by Amnesty International claim the suspect’s gun “malfunctioned” when he tried to fire at police, after which they shot and killed him. In many instances, the police try to cover up unlawful killings or ensure convictions for those arrested during drug-related operations by planting “evidence” at crime scenes and falsifying incident reports—both practices the police officer said were common.|Amnesty International report ''“If you are poor you are killed”: Extrajudicial Executions in the Philippines’ “War on Drugs”''{{cite web|title=PHILIPPINES: "IF YOU ARE POOR, YOU ARE KILLED": EXTRAJUDICIAL KILLINGS IN THE PHILIPPINES' "WAR ON DRUGS"|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/asa35/5517/2017/en/|publisher=Amnesty International|accessdate=12 February 2017}}}} The report makes a series of recommendations to Duterte and government officials and departments. If certain key steps are not swiftly taken, it recommends that the [[International Criminal Court]] "initiate a preliminary examination into unlawful killings in the Philippines’s violent anti-drug campaign and related crimes under the [[Rome Statute]], including the involvement of government officials, irrespective of rank and status." The Guardian and Reuters stated that the report added to evidence they had published previously about police extrajudicial executions. Presidential spokesman Ernesto Abella responded to the report, saying that Senate committee investigations proved that there had been no state-sponsored extrajudicial killings.{{cite news|title=Philippines police behave like 'criminal underworld' in drugs war - Amnesty|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-drugs-report-idUSKBN15F208|accessdate=February 8, 2017|agency=Reuters|date=February 1, 2017}}{{cite news|title=Philippines police paid to kill alleged drug offenders, says Amnesty|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jan/31/philippines-police-paid-to-kill-alleged-drug-offenders-says-amnesty-rodrigo-duterte|accessdate=February 13, 2017|work=The Guardian|date=January 31, 2017}} In an interview on February 4, Duterte told a reporter that Amnesty International was "so naive and so stupid", and "a creation of [George] [[George Soros|Soros]]". He asked, "Is that the only thing you [de Lima] can produce? The report of Amnesty?"{{cite news|title=‘Amnesty lnternational naive and stupid’|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/02/06/1669510/amnesty-lnternational-naive-and-stupid|accessdate=February 24, 2017|work=Philstar|date=February 6, 2017}} De Lima was jailed on February 24, awaiting trial on charges related to allegations made by Duterte in August 2016.{{cite news|title=Philippines: Duterte critic De Lima arrested on drug-related charges|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/02/23/asia/philippines-duterte-critic-de-lima-arrested/index.html|accessdate=29 September 2017|work=CNN|date=March 1, 2017}} A court date has not been set.{{cite news|title=Jailed Philippine Senator: 'I Won't Be Silenced Or Cowed'|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/06/24/533794081/jailed-philippine-senator-i-wont-be-silenced-or-cowed|accessdate=29 September 2017|work=NPR|date=June 24, 2017}} ===Arturo Lascañas=== On February 20, [[Arturo Lascañas]], a retired police officer, told reporters at a press conference outside the senate building that as a leader of the Davao Death Squad he had carried out extrajudicial killings on the orders of Duterte. He said death squad members were paid 20,000 to 100,000 pesos ($400 to $2,000) per hit, depending on the importance of the target. He gave details of various killings he had carried out on Duterte's orders, including the previously unsolved murder of a radio show host critical of Duterte, and confessed to his involvement with Matobato in the bombing of a mosque on Duterte's orders.{{cite news|title=Retired Philippine policeman says Duterte ordered 'death squad' hits|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-drugs/retired-philippine-policeman-says-duterte-ordered-death-squad-hits-idUSKBN15Z0C8|accessdate=October 4, 2017|agency=Reuters|date=February 20, 2017}}{{cite news|title=Retired SPO3 Lascanas: What he said before, what he now says|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/02/20/17/retired-spo3-lascanas-what-he-said-before-what-he-now-says|accessdate=October 4, 2017|publisher=ABS CBN|date=February 20, 2017}} On the following day the senate voted in a private session to reopen the investigation, reportedly by a margin of ten votes to eight, with five abstentions.{{cite news|title=Senate to reopen probe into Davao Death Squad|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/162161-senate-reopen-probe-davao-death-squad|accessdate=October 6, 2017|work=Rappler|date=February 21, 2017}} {{quote|When Mayor Duterte sat down as mayor for the first time, we started what is called "salvaging" of people, these people are suspects committing crime in Davao. We implemented the personal orders of Mayor Duterte to us.|Arturo Lascanas, February 20, 2017}} On March 6, Lascanas gave evidence at the Senate committee, testifying that he had killed approximately 200 criminal suspects, media figures and political opponents on Duterte's orders.{{cite news|title=Self-proclaimed death squad chief: I killed almost 200 for Duterte|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/03/06/asia/davao-death-squad-leader-testimony/index.html|accessdate=October 6, 2017|publisher=CNN|date=March 6, 2017}} ===Allegations of police using hospitals to hide killings=== In June 2017 Reuters reported that "Police were sending corpses to hospitals to destroy evidence at crime scenes and hide the fact that they were executing drug suspects." Doctors stated that corpses loaded onto trucks were being dumped at hospitals, sometimes after [[rigor mortis]] had already set in, with clearly unsurvivable wounds, having been shot in the chest and head at close range. Reuters examined data from two Manila police districts, and found that the proportion of suspects sent to hospitals, where they are pronounced dead on arrival (DOA), increased from 13% in July 2016 to 85% in January 2017; "The totals grew along with international and domestic condemnation of Duterte's campaign."{{cite news|title=Philippine police use hospitals to hide drug war killings|url=https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/philippines-duterta-doa/|accessdate=23 September 2017|agency=Reuters|date=June 29, 2017}} ===Ozamiz raid, and death of Reynaldo Parojinog=== On July 30, Reynaldo Parojinog, the mayor of [[Ozamiz]] City, was killed along with 14 others, including his wife Susan, in a [[2017 Ozamiz police raid|dawn raid]] at around 2:30 am on his home in San Roque Lawis.{{cite news|title=Ozamiz City Mayor, 14 others killed in exchange of gunfire with police|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/07/30/Ozamiz-Mayor-killed-in-police-raid.html|publisher=CNN Philippines|accessdate=July 30, 2017}}{{cite news|last=Nawal|first=Allan|title=Mayor Parojinog killed in Ozamiz raid; daughter arrested — police|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/918778/cidg-raids-parojinog-houses-8-reported-dead|publisher=Inquirer.net|accessdate=July 30, 2017}} According to police, they were on a search warrant when Parojinog's bodyguards opened fire on them and police officers responded by shooting at them. According to police provincial chief Jaysen De Guzman, authorities recovered grenades, ammunition and illegal drugs in the raid.{{cite news|title=Ozamiz City Mayor, twelve others killed in police raid|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/07/30/Ozamiz-Mayor-killed-in-police-raid.html|publisher=CNN Philippines|accessdate=July 30, 2017}}{{cite news|title=Philippine mayor linked to drugs killed in raid: police|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20170730-philippine-mayor-linked-drugs-killed-raid-police|agency=[[France 24]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730102021/http://www.france24.com/en/20170730-philippine-mayor-linked-drugs-killed-raid-police|archive-date=July 30, 2017|dead-url=yes|accessdate=July 30, 2017}} ==="One-time, big-time" operations=== On August 16, over 32 people were killed in multiple "one-time, big-time" antidrug operations in Bulacan within one day.{{Cite news|last=Talabong|first=Rambo|title=32 dead, 107 arrested in Bulacan 'one-time, big-time' operation|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/178900-32-dead-107-arrested-bulacan-war-against-drugs-operation|agency=Rappler|date=August 16, 2017|accessdate=August 21, 2017}} On [[Manila]], 25 people, including 11 suspected robbers, were also killed in consecutive anti-criminality operations.{{Cite news|last=Pilapil|first=Jaime|title=25 dead over 24 hours in 'one-time, big-time' police operations in Manila|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/25-dead-over-24-hours-one-time-big-time-police-operations-manila/344991/|newspaper=[[The Manila Times]]|date=August 17, 2017|accessdate=August 21, 2017}} The multiple deaths in the large-scale antidrug operations received condemnation from human rights groups and the majority of the Senate.{{cite news|last=Mogato|first=Manuel|title=Philippines war on drugs and crime intensifies, at least 60 killed in three days|url=https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/philippines-war-on-drugs-and-crime-intensifies--at-least-58-killed-this-week/43417928|agency=Reuters|date=August 17, 2017|accessdate=August 21, 2017|via=[[Swissinfo.ch]]}}{{cite news|last1=Ballaran|first1=Jhoanna|last2=de Jesus|first2=Julianne Love|title=Senators expressed alarm over high number of drug deaths|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/923723/senate-of-the-philippines-senator-kiko-pangilinan-drug-deaths-war-on-drugs-anti-drug-operations-drug-problem-poor-filipinos-customs-jv-ejercito-grace-poe|work=Inquirer.net|publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=August 18, 2017|accessdate=August 21, 2017}} ===Youth casualties=== {{main|Shooting of Kian Loyd delos Santos}} On August 17, Kian Loyd delos Santos, a 17-year-old Grade 11 student, was shot dead in an antidrug operation in Caloocan.{{cite news|last=Subingsubing|first=Krixia|title=Cops kill 'pistol-packing' Grade 11 kid|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/923639/cops-kill-pistol-packing-grade-11-kid|newspaper=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=August 18, 2017|accessdate=August 21, 2017}} CCTV footage appeared to show Kian being dragged by two policemen. Police say they killed him in self-defense, and retrieved a gun and two packets of methamphetamine.{{Cite news|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/metro/622230/grade-11-student-killed-during-anti-drug-op-in-caloocan/story/|title=Grade 11 student killed during anti-drug op in Caloocan|agency=GMA News|date=August 17, 2017|accessdate=August 21, 2017}} Delos Santos was the son of an [[overseas Filipino worker]], a key demographic in support of Duterte.{{cite news|title=After Kian slay, Duterte tempers messaging on drug war|url=https://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/in-depth/180006-kian-delos-santos-duterte-tempers-messaging-drug-war|accessdate=29 September 2017|work=Rappler|date=August 26, 2017}} The teenager's death caused condemnation by senators.{{Cite news|last=Morallo|first=Audrey|title=17-year old's death jolts senators to speak vs. killings|url=http://m.philstar.com/782974/show/a07a2213d8a93d907ec948ac30a63b01/? |newspaper=The Philippine Star|date=August 18, 2017|accessdate=August 21, 2017}}{{cite news|title=Human rights commission province 'one time, big time' drug ops, Kian's death|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/622612/human-rights-commission-probing-one-time-big-time-drug-ops-kian-s-death/story/|agency=GMA News|date=August 20, 2017|accessdate=August 21, 2017}} His funeral on August 25, attended by more than a thousand people, was one of the largest protests to date against the Drug War.{{cite news|title=More than a thousand turn Philippine funeral to protest against war on drugs|url=https://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCAKCN1B604A-OCATP|accessdate=2 October 2017|agency=Reuters|date=August 26, 2017}} Carl Angelo Arnaiz, a 19-year-old teenager, last found in Cainta, Rizal, was tortured and shot dead also on August 17 (the same date Kian delos Santos was killed) by police after robbing a taxi in Caloocan.{{cite news|last=Placido|first=Dharel|title=Duterte to pursue raps vs. cops in Carl Angelo's killing|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/09/06/17/duterte-to-pursue-raps-vs-cops-in-carl-angelos-killing|agency=[[ABS-CBN News]]|date=September 6, 2017|accessdate=September 10, 2017}} His 14-year-old friend, Reynaldo de Guzman, also called under the nickname "Kulot", was stabbed to death thirty times and thrown into a creek in [[Gapan]], Nueva Ecija. Along with the deaths of Kian delos Santos, the deaths of the two teenagers also triggered public outrage and condemnation.{{cite news|last=Talabong|first=Rambo|title=Missing teen last found with Carl Arnaiz found dead with 30 stab wounds|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/181324-missing-teen-reynaldo-de-guzman-dead-nueva-ecija|agency=Rappler|date=September 6, 2017|accessdate=September 10, 2017}} Human Rights Watch repeated their call for a UN investigation. HRW Asia director Phelim Kine commented: "The apparent willingness of Philippine police to deliberately target children for execution marks an appalling new level of depravity in this so-called drug war". Duterte called the deaths of Arnaiz and de Guzman (the former being a relative of the President on his mother's side) a "sabotage", believing that some groups are using the Philippine National Police to destroy the president's public image.{{cite news|last=Salaverria|first=Leila B.|title=Teens' killing sabotage-Duterte|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/929089/philippine-news-updates-president-duterte-teen-killings-war-on-drugs-2|work=Inquirer.net|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=September 9, 2017|accessdate=September 10, 2017}} Presidential spokesman Abella said "It should not come as a surprise that these malignant elements would conspire to sabotage the president’s campaign to rid the Philippines of illegal drugs and criminality", which "may include creating scenarios stoking public anger against the government".{{cite news|title=The death of a Philippine teen was supposed to be a turning point for Duterte. But kids keep getting killed.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/09/11/the-death-of-a-philippine-teen-was-supposed-to-be-a-turning-point-for-duterte-but-kids-keep-getting-killed/|accessdate=8 October 2017|work=Washington Post|date=September 11, 2017}} On August 23, 2016, a 5-year-old student named Danica May Garcia was killed by a stray bullet coming from the unidentified gunmen in [[Dagupan City, Pangasinan]] during an anti-drug operation.{{cite news |title=Collateral damage: 5-yr-old girl latest fatality in war on drugs |url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/144138-five-year-old-killed-pangasinan-war-drugs |work=[[Rappler]]}} Another minor, 4-year old Skyler Abatayo of Cebu was killed through an 'anti-drug operation'. Duterte insisted that the child was killed by drug suspects, not by his police force.{{cite news |title=4-year-old killed by stray bullet from Cebu City anti-drug operation |url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/206962-skyler-abatayo-killed-stray-bullet-anti-drug-operation-cebu-city |work=[[Rappler]]}} In the first year of the Drug War, 54 children were recorded as casualties. ===Reshuffling of the Caloocan City Police=== As a result of involvement in the deaths of teenagers like Kian delos Santos, and Carl Angelo Arnaiz and Reynaldo de Guzman, and robbing of a drug suspect in an antidrug raid, National Capital Region Police Office (NCRPO) chief Oscar Albayalde ordered the firing and retraining of all members of the Caloocan City Police, with the exception of its newly appointed chief and its deputy.{{Cite news|last1=Alquitran|first1=Non|last2=Galupo|first2=Rey|title=Entire Caloocan City police force sacked|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/09/16/1739626/entire-caloocan-city-police-force-sacked|newspaper=The Philippine Star|publisher=Philstar|date=September 16, 2017|accessdate=September 18, 2017}} ===Transfer of anti-drug operations to PDEA=== On October 12, 2017, Duterte announced the transfer of anti-drug operations to the Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency (PDEA), ending the involvement of the Philippine National Police (PNP). The announcement followed the publication of an opinion poll on October 8, showing a drop in presidential approval from 66% to 48%.{{cite news|title=The Mutineer: How Antonio Trillanes Came to Lead the Fight Against Rodrigo Duterte|url=http://time.com/4971952/antonio-trillanes-rodrigo-duterte-philippines/|accessdate=October 29, 2017|work=Time|date=October 27, 2017}} This is amidst the political storm and public outrage on the murders of minors by the Caloocan City police, and the various murder cases allegedly done by other law enforcement agents that surfaced in mainstream and social media.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/180209-kian-is-your-conscience|title=Kian is your conscience|work=Rappler|access-date=2017-10-28}} In a televised speech, Duterte scoffed and mocked the "bleeding hearts" who sympathized with those killed in the drug war, pointedly at the European Union, whom he accused of interfering with Philippine sovereignty.{{Cite news|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/10/12/17/duterte-hopes-drug-war-shift-will-satisfy-bleeding-hearts|title=Duterte hopes drug war shift will satisfy 'bleeding hearts'|last=Reuters|first=Manuel Mogato and Neil Jerome Morales,|work=ABS-CBN News|access-date=2017-10-28}} ===Rodrigo Duterte's refutation to ASEAN representatives=== In a speech before [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations|ASEAN]] representatives, Rodrigo Duterte refuted all extrajudicial killings related to the War on Drugs by stating that these stories only serve as a political agenda in order to demonize him. He stated that he has only used his mouth to tell drug users that they will be killed. He stated that "..."shabu" (crystal meth) users have shrunken brains, which is why they have become violent and aggressive, leading to their deaths."{{Cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/940922/ive-been-demonized-in-drug-war-duterte|title=I’ve been demonized in drug war–Duterte|last=Salaverria|first=Leila B.|access-date=2018-02-28}} Duterte further added that all the drug pushers and their henchmen always carry their guns with them and killing them is justifiable so that they would not endanger the lives of his men.{{Cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/940922/ive-been-demonized-in-drug-war-duterte|title=I’ve been demonized in drug war–Duterte|last=Salaverria|first=Leila B.|access-date=2017-10-28}} Duterte appointed a human rights lawyer, [[Harry Roque]], a Kabayan partylist representative, as his spokesperson. Roque stated that he will change public perception by reducing the impact of the statements by which Duterte advocates extra-judicial killings in his war on drugs.{{Cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/941212/roque-to-reduce-impact-of-duterte-statements-seeming-to-back-rights-violations|title=Roque to ‘reduce impact’ of Duterte statements seeming to back rights violations|last=Nonato|first=Vince F.|access-date=2017-10-28}} ===2018=== In a speech on March 26, 2018, Duterte said that human rights groups "have become unwitting tools of drug lords". Human Rights Watch denied the allegation, calling it "shockingly dangerous and shameful".{{cite news |title=Body Count Piles Up in Philippine Drug War |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/body-count-piles-up-in-philippine-drug-war-1522134883 |accessdate=October 19, 2018 |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=March 27, 2018}} ====Consecutive assassinations of local government officials==== {{further information|Assassination of Antonio Halili}} The controversial [[Tanauan, Batangas]] mayor [[Antonio Halili]] was assassinated by an unknown sniper during a flag-raising ceremony on July 2, 2018, becoming the 11th local government official to be killed in the Drug War. On the following day, Ferdinand Bote, mayor of General Tinio, was shot dead in his vehicle in Cabanatuan City.{{cite news|last=Osborne|first=Samuel|title=Philippine mayor assassinated day after another was shot dead|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/ferdinand-bote-killed-assassinated-philippines-mayor-nueva-ecija-antonio-halili-a8429121.html?amp|newspaper=[[The Independent]]}}{{cite news |title=FAST FACTS: Who is slain General Tinio Mayor Ferdinand Bote? |url=https://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/iq/206422-things-to-know-slain-general-tinio-nueva-ecija-mayor-ferdinand-bote |accessdate=October 19, 2018 |work=Rappler |date=July 3, 2018}} ==International Criminal Court== The [[International Criminal Court]] (ICC) chief prosecutor [[Fatou Bensouda]] expressed concern, over the drug-related killings in the country, on October 13, 2016.{{cite news|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/10/14/Intl-Criminal-Court-chief-prosecutor-warns-PH-over-drug-killings.html|title=Int'l Criminal Court chief prosecutor warns PH over drug killings|work=CNN Philippines}} In her statement, Bensouda said that the high officials of the country "seem to condone such killings and further seem to encourage State forces and civilians alike to continue targeting these individuals with lethal force."{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/149135-international-criminal-court-philippines|title=Int'l criminal court 'closely following' PH war on drugs|work=Rappler}} She also warns that any person in the country who provoke "in acts of mass violence by ordering, requesting, encouraging or contributing, in any other manner, to the commission of crimes within the jurisdiction of ICC" will be prosecuted before the court.{{cite news|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/146810/international-court-warns-ph-on-killings|title=International court warns PH on killings|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer}} About that, Duterte is open for the investigation by the ICC, Malacañang said. In February 2018, the ICC announced a “preliminary examination” into killings linked to the Philippine government's “war on drugs”. Prosecutor Bensouda said the court will “analyze crimes allegedly committed in [the Philippines] since at least 1 July 2016.” Duterte's spokesman Harry Roque dismissed the ICC's decision as a “waste of the court’s time and resources”.{{cite web|url=https://www.icc-cpi.int/Pages/item.aspx?name=180208-otp-stat|title=Statement of the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, Mrs Fatou Bensouda, on opening Preliminary Examinations into the situations in the Philippines and in Venezuela|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2018/02/08/philippines-murderous-drug-war-icc-crosshairs|title=Philippines Murderous ‘Drug War’ in ICC Crosshairs|date=8 February 2018|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.icc-cpi.int/iccdocs/otp/OTP-Policy_Paper_Preliminary_Examinations_2013-ENG.pdf|title=''Policy Paper on Preliminary Examinations''|publisher=}} In March, Duterte announced his intention to withdraw the Philippines from the ICC tribunal, which is a process that takes a year.{{cite news |title=Duterte Is Accused of Murder in New Filing at Hague Court |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/28/world/asia/philippines-duterte-hague.html?module=inline |accessdate=October 15, 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=August 28, 2018}} In August 2018, activists and eight families of victims of the Drug War filed a second petition with the ICC, accusing Duterte of murder and crimes against humanity, and calling for his indictment for thousands of extrajudicial killings, which according to the 50-page complaint included "brazen" executions by police acting with impunity. Neri Colmenares, a lawyer acting for the group, said that "Duterte is personally liable for ordering state police to undertake mass killings". Duterte threatened to arrest the ICC prosecutor Bensouda.{{cite news |title=Philippines' Duterte hit by new ICC complaint over deadly drug war |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-drugs/philippines-duterte-hit-by-new-icc-complaint-over-deadly-drug-war-idUSKCN1LD0CS |accessdate=October 19, 2018 |agency=Reuters |date=August 28, 2018}} ==Reactions== ===Local=== {{Expand section|date=August 2018}} Senator [[Risa Hontiveros]], an opponent of Duterte, said that the Drug War was a political strategy intended to persuade people that "suddenly the historically most important issue of poverty was no longer the most important." De Lima expressed frustration with the attitude of Filipinos towards extrajudicial killing: "they think that it's good for peace and order. We now have death squads on a national scale, but I'm not seeing public outrage." According to a [[Pulse Asia]] opinion poll conducted from July 2 to 8, 2016, 91% of Filipinos "trusted" Duterte.{{cite news|title=Duterte enjoys record-high 91% trust rating – Pulse Asia|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/140318-duterte-trust-rating-july-2016|accessdate=October 3, 2016|work=Rappler|date=September 22, 2016}} A survey conducted between February and May 2017, by PEW research center, found that 78% of the Filipinos support the drug war.{{cite web|url=http://assets.pewresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2017/09/20171150/Pew-Research-Center_Philippines-Report_2017.09.21.pdf|title=People in the Philippines Still Favor U.S. Over China, but Gap Is Narrowing (2017), Pew Research Center, p. 4|publisher=|accessdate=November 19, 2017}} A survey in September 2017 showed 88% support for the Drug War, while 73% believed that extrajudicial executions were occurring.{{cite news |title=Philippine survey shows big support for Duterte's drugs war |url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-philippines-drugs/philippine-survey-shows-big-support-for-dutertes-drugs-war-idUKKBN1CL0JK |accessdate=October 13, 2018 |agency=Reuters |date=October 16, 2017}} Dela Rosa announced in September 2016 that the Drug War had "reduced the supply of illegal drugs in the country by some 80 to 90 percent",{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/581640/news/nation/pnp-chief-illegal-drug-supply-already-reduced-by-80-90-percent|title=PNP chief: Illegal drug supply already reduced by 80-90 percent|date=September 16, 2016|website=GMA Network}} and said that the War was already being won, based on statistical and observational evidence.{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/147423-dela-rosa-winning-war-drugs|title=Dela Rosa: We’re winning the war on drugs|publisher=}} ''Aljazeera'' reported that John Collins, director of the [[LSE IDEAS|London School of Economics International Drug Policy Project]], said: "Targeting the supply side can have short-term effects. However, these are usually limited to creating market chaos rather than reducing the size of the market. ... What you learn is that you're going to war with a force of economics and the force of economics tends to win out: supply, demand and price tend to find their own way." He said it was a "certainty" that "the Philippines' new 'war' will fail and society will emerge worse off from it."{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2016/09/philippines-duterte-killer-drug-war-160905094258461.html|title=Philippines: Inside Duterte's killer drug war|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=8 September 2016|accessdate=2 October 2016}} In June 2017 the price of methamphetamine on the streets of Manila was lower than it had been at the start of Duterte's presidency, according to Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency data. Gloria Lai of the [[International Drug Policy Consortium]] commented: "If prices have fallen, it's an indication that enforcement actions have not been effective".{{cite news|title=More blood but no victory as Philippine drug war marks its first year|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-duterte-drugs/more-blood-but-no-victory-as-philippine-drug-war-marks-its-first-year-idUSKBN19G05D|accessdate=19 September 2017|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=25 June 2017}} The Chairman of the Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry, [[Sergio Ortiz-Luis Jr.]], quelled fears that foreign investors might be put off by the increasing rate of killings in the country, explaining at a press conference on September 19, 2016, that investors only care about profit: "They don't care if 50 percent of Filipinos are killing each other so long as they're not affected".{{cite news |url=http://cnnphilippines.com/business/2016/09/20/biz-men-speak-up-about-war-on-drugs.html |title='Foreign investors care about money, not drug deaths' — biz leader |work=CNN Philippines |date=September 20, 2016 |accessdate=September 21, 2016 }} On the following day the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that foreign investors, who account for half of the activity on the [[Philippine Stock Exchange]], had been "hightailing it out of town", selling $500 million worth of shares over the past month, putting pressure on the [[Philippine peso]] which was close to its weakest point since 2009.{{cite news |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2016/09/20/in-dutertes-philippines-foreigners-flee-stocks/ |title=In Duterte's Philippines, Foreigners Flee Stocks |work=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=September 20, 2016 |accessdate=September 23, 2016 }} The Archbishop of Manila [[Luis Antonio Tagle]] acknowledged that people were right to be "worried about extrajudicial killings", along with other "form[s] of murder": abortion, unfair labor practices, wasting food, and "selling illegal drugs, pushing the youth to go into vices".{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/144517-philippines-cardinal-tagle-extrajudicial-killings-war-drugs|title=Cardinal Tagle breaks silence: Condemn murder|publisher=}} ===International=== [[File:Philippines Drug War Protest 2.jpg|thumb|Protest against the Philippine war on drugs in front of the Philippine Consulate General in [[New York City]]. The protesters are holding placards which urge Duterte to stop killing drug users.]] During his official state visit to the Philippines in January 2017, Japanese Prime Minister [[Shinzō Abe]] said: "On countering illegal drugs, we want to work together with the Philippines through relevant measures of support". He offered financial assistance for Philippine drug rehabilitation centres, and made no mention of deaths resulting from the drug war. He announced a $800 million [[Official Development Assistance (Japan)|Official Development Assistance]] package to "promote economic and infrastructure development".{{cite news|title=Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's 'War on Drugs'|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/09/07/philippine-president-rodrigo-dutertes-war-drugs|accessdate=8 October 2017|publisher=Human Rights Watch|date=September 7, 2017}} Gary Song-Huann Lin, the representative of [[Taiwan]] in the Philippines, welcomed Duterte's plan to declare a war against criminality and illegal drugs. He said Taiwan is ready to help the Philippines combat cross-border crimes like human and drug trafficking.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/06/14/1592910/taiwan-confident-stronger-ties-philippines-under-duterte|title=Taiwan confident of stronger ties with Philippines under Duterte|author=Alexis Romero|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=June 14, 2016|accessdate=November 5, 2016}} On July 19, 2016, Lingxiao Li, spokesman for the Chinese Embassy in Manila, announced [[China]]'s support for the Drug War: "China fully understands that the Philippine government under the leadership of H. E. President Rodrigo Duterte has taken it as a top priority to crack down drug-related crimes. China has expressed explicitly to the new administration China's willingness for effective cooperation in this regard, and would like to work out a specific plan of action with the Philippine side." The statement made no reference to extrajudicial killings, and called illegal drugs the "common enemy of mankind".{{cite news|title=China supports Duterte's war on drugs|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/07/19/16/china-supports-dutertes-war-on-drugs|accessdate=22 August 2016|work=ABS-CBN News|date=July 9, 2016}}{{cite news|title=China answers Duterte's call on illegal drugs: We're ready to help|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/140228-china-duterte-illegal-drugs-cooperate|accessdate=October 12, 2016|work=Rappler|date=July 19, 2016}}{{cite news|title=Beijing backs Philippine President Duterte’s ruthless crackdown on drugs|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/1992219/beijing-backs-philippine-president-dutertes-ruthless|accessdate=October 12, 2016|work=South China Morning Post|date=July 20, 2016}} On September 27, the Chinese Ambassador Zhao Jianhua reiterated that "Illegal drugs are the enemy of all mankind" in a statement confirming Chinese support for the Duterte administration.{{cite news|title=China envoy: Illegal drugs 'enemy of all mankind'|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/147569-china-ambassador-philippines-illegal-drugs-enemy-mankind|accessdate=October 12, 2016|work=Rappler|date=September 28, 2016}} [[Indonesian National Police]] Chief General [[Tito Karnavian]] commented in regards to Indonesia's rejection of a similar policy for Indonesia: "Shoot on sight policy leads to abuse of power. We still believe in the presumption of innocence. Lethal actions are only warranted if there is an immediate threat against officers... there should not be a deliberate attempt to kill".{{cite web|url=http://jakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/news/indonesia-will-not-adopt-philippines-shoot-sight-policy-drug-criminals/|title=Indonesia Will Not Adopt the Philippines' 'Shoot on Sight' Policy Against Drug Criminals - Jakarta Globe|publisher=}} In September 2016 Budi Waseso, head of Indonesia's [[National Anti-Narcotics Agency (Indonesia)|National Anti-Narcotics Agency (BNN)]], said that he was currently contemplating copying the Philippines' hardline tactics against drug traffickers. He said that the Agency planned a major increase in armaments and recruitment. An Agency spokesman later attempted to downplay the comments, stating: "We can't shoot criminals just like that, we have to follow the rules."{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-09-08/indonesian-official-wants-philippine-style-drug-war/7824696|title=Indonesian anti-drugs chief supports implementing Rodrigo Duterte's Philippine-style drug war…|publisher=''[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]''|date=September 8, 2016}} Most recently, Indonesian President [[Joko Widodo|Joko “Jokowi” Widodo]] used the language of “emergency” to ramp up the country's war on drugs, in a move that observers see as "in step with Filipino President Rodrigo Duterte’s" own campaign against the illegal drug trade.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/indonesia-war-on-drugs/3981443.html|title=Indonesia' war on drugs=}} On October 16, prior to Duterte's departure for a state visit to [[Brunei]], the President said he would seek the support of that country for his campaign against illegal drugs and Brunei's continued assistance to achieve peace and progress in Mindanao.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/10/17/1634364/brunei-asked-support-drug-war-peace-process|title=Brunei asked to support drug war, peace process|author1=Giovanni Nilles|author2=Edith Regalado|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=October 17, 2016|accessdate=October 19, 2016}} This was responded positively from Brunei Sultan [[Hassanal Bolkiah]] in the next day according to Philippine Foreign Affairs Secretary [[Perfecto Yasay Jr.]]{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/10/18/1634725/brunei-backs-philippines-war-drugs|title=Brunei backs Philippines in war on drugs|author=Edith Regalado|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=October 18, 2016|accessdate=October 19, 2016}} [[Malaysia]]'s Deputy Prime Minister [[Ahmad Zahid Hamidi]] said "he respect the method undertaken by the Philippine government as it is suitable for their country situation", while stressing that "Malaysia will never follow such example as we have our own methods with one of those such as seizing assets used in drug trafficking with resultant funds to be channelled back towards rehabilitation, prevention and enforcement of laws against drugs".{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/malaysia-wont-copy-philippines-deadly-drug-war-says-dpm|title=Malaysia won’t copy Philippines’ deadly drug war, says DPM|author=Kamles Kumar|publisher=The Malay Mail|date=October 25, 2016|accessdate=October 25, 2016}} On December 3, 2016, Duterte said that during a phone conversation on the previous day with then-United States President-elect [[Donald Trump]], Trump had invited him to Washington, and endorsed his Drug War policy, assuring him that it was being conducted "the right way".{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4589671/rodrigo-duterte-donald-trump-antidrug-campaign/|title=Rodrigo Duterte: Donald Trump Endorsed Deadly War on Drugs as 'The Right Way'|website=Time}} Duterte described the conversation: {{quote|I could sense a good rapport, an animated President-elect Trump. And he was wishing me success in my campaign against the drug problem. [...] He understood the way we are handling it, and I said that there’s nothing wrong in protecting a country. It was a bit very encouraging in the sense that I supposed that what he really wanted to say was that we would be the last to interfere in the affairs of your own country.{{cite news |title=Rodrigo Duterte Says Donald Trump Endorses His Violent Antidrug Campaign |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/03/world/asia/philippines-rodrigo-duterte-donald-trump.html |accessdate=October 14, 2018 |work=New York Times |date=December 3, 2016}}}} On December 16, Duterte and Singaporean President [[Tony Tan]] and Prime Minister [[Lee Hsien Loong]] agreed to work together in the fight against terrorism and illegal drugs. In a meeting during a state visit both parties discussed areas of cooperation between the two countries.{{cite web|url=https://themochapost.com/2016/12/16/ph-singapore-one-war-drugs-terrorism/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170909095730/https://themochapost.com/2016/12/16/ph-singapore-one-war-drugs-terrorism/|archivedate=2017-09-09|title=PH and Singapore One with the War Against Drugs and Terrorism|publisher=TheMochaPost|date=December 16, 2016|accessdate=February 20, 2017}} The [[European Parliament]] expressed concern over the extrajudicial killings after a resolution on September 15, stating: "Drug trafficking and drug abuse in the Philippines remain a serious national and international concern, note MEPs. They understand that millions of people are hurt by the high level of drug addiction and its consequences in the country but are also concerned by the 'extraordinarily high numbers killed during police operations in the context of an intensified anti-crime and anti-drug campaign."{{cite news|title=European Parliament urges PH: End wave of killings|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/146535-european-parliament-philippines-end-wave-extrajudicial-killings|work=Rappler|date=September 17, 2016}} In response, at a press conference Duterte made an [[The finger|obscene hand gesture]] and called British and French representatives "hypocrites" because their ancestors had killed thousands of Arabs and others in the colonial era. He said: "When I read the EU condemnation I told them fuck you. You are doing it in atonement for your sins. They are now strict because they have guilty feelings. Who did I kill? Assuming that it's true? 1,700? How many have they killed?"{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/rodrigo-duterte-eu-f-you-expletive-philippines-attack-parliament-obama-a7319836.html |title=Philippines president Rodrigo Duterte tells the EU 'F***you' over his war on drugs |work=The Independent |date=September 21, 2016 |accessdate=October 2, 2016 }}{{cite news|title=Duterte gives middle finger to EU lawmakers again|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/147032-duterte-curses-european-union|work=Rappler}} EU Trade Commissioner [[Cecilia Malmström]], in a visit to the Philippines in March 2017, warned that unless the Philippines addresses human rights issues, the EU would cancel tariff-free export of 6,000 products under the [[Generalized System of Preferences]]. Presidential spokesman [[Ernesto Abella]] dismissed the concerns, saying that they revealed European ignorance. On December 24, U.S. Senators [[Marco Rubio]], [[Edward Markey]], and [[Chris Coons|Christopher Coons]] expressed their concerns regarding the alleged extrajudicial killings and human rights violations in Duterte's war on drugs. Through a letter sent to the [[United States Department of State|U.S. Department of State]], they noted that instead of addressing the drug problem, investing in treatment programs or approaching the issue with an emphasis on health, Duterte has "pledged to kill another 20,000 to 30,000 people, many simply because they suffer from a drug use disorder." Rubio, Markey and Coons also questioned U.S. secretary of state [[John Kerry]]'s pledge of $32-million funding for training and other law-enforcement assistance during his visit to Manila.{{cite news|title=Duterte's drug war a 'campaign of mass atrocities': US senators|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/12/24/16/dutertes-drug-war-a-campaign-of-mass-atrocities-us-senators|work=ABS-CBN News}}{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/12/28/1657489/us-senators-want-tracking-funds-philippines-amid-drug-war|title=US senators want tracking of funds in Philippines amid drug war|author1=Patricia Lourdes Viray|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=October 17, 2016|accessdate=October 19, 2016}} In May 2017, Senator Rubio, along with Senator [[Ben Cardin]], filed a [[Bipartisanship|bipartisan]] bill in the U.S. Senate to restrict the exportation of weapons from the U.S. to the Philippines.{{cite news|last1=Marcelo|first1=Ver|title=U.S. Senators file bill to block arms export to PH|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/05/05/us-senators-bill-to-block-arms-export-to-PH.html|accessdate=May 6, 2017|publisher=[[CNN Philippines]]|date=May 5, 2017}} The US ambassador in Manila announced on December 14, 2016, that the US foreign aid agency, the [[Millennium Challenge Corporation]], would cancel funding to the Philippines due to "significant concerns around rule of law and civil liberties in the Philippines", explaining that aid recipients were required to demonstrate a "commitment to the rule of law, due process and respect for human rights". The MCC had disbursed $434 million to the Philippines from 2011 to 2015. The funding denial was expected to lead to the cancellation of a five-year infrastructure development project previously agreed to in December 2015. In February 2017, former [[Colombia]]n President [[César Gaviria]] wrote an opinion piece on ''[[The New York Times]]'' to warn Duterte and the administration that the drug war is "unwinnable" and "disastrous", citing his own experiences as the President of Colombia. He also criticized the alleged extrajudicial killings and vigilantism, saying these are "the wrong ways to go". According to Gaviria, the war on drugs is essentially a war on people.{{cite web|url=https://themochapost.com/2017/02/08/former-colombian-presidents-take-philippine-drug-war/ |title=Former Colombian Presidents take Philippine Drug War|publisher=TheMochaPost|accessdate=February 16, 2017}} Gaviria suggested that improving [[public health]] and safety, strengthening anti-corruption measures, investing in [[sustainable development]], decriminalizing drug consumption, and strengthening the [[regulation of therapeutic goods]] would enhance [[Supply reduction|supply]] and [[demand reduction]]. In response to Gaviria, Duterte called him an "idiot", and said the issue of extrajudicial killings should be set aside, and that there were four to five million drug addicts in the country.{{cite news|author1=[[César Gaviria|Gaviria, César]]|title=President Duterte Is Repeating My Mistakes|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/07/opinion/president-duterte-is-repeating-my-mistakes.html?smid=tw-share&_r=0|accessdate=February 8, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 7, 2017}}{{cite news|title=Duterte calls Colombian ex-president 'idiot'|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/02/08/1670271/duterte-calls-colombian-ex-president-idiot|work=Philstar}} In September 2017, Foreign Affairs Secretary Alan Peter Cayetano delivered a speech at the 72nd United Nations General Assembly, during which he argued that extrajudicial killings were a myth, and that the Drug war, which according to Human Rights Watch has resulted in 13,000 deaths to date, was being waged to "protect (the) human rights of...the most vulnerable (citizens)".{{cite web|url=http://usa.inquirer.net/8246/asean-un-sec-cayetanos-sophistry|title=Asean, the UN and Sec. Cayetano's sophistry|website=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=November 22, 2017}} In October 2017, Secretary Cayetano was interviewed by the Qatari news outlet al-Jazeera. He asserted that all 3,900 people who were killed in the drug war fought against the police despite there having been no investigations conducted prior to the drug busts. He also rebuffed all claims that the drug war was against its people.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/upfront/2017/10/philippines-defends-duterte-drug-war-171006085311620.html|title=How the Philippines defends Duterte's drug war|website=[[Al Jazeera]]|accessdate=19 November 2017}} ===38-nation statement against the drug war=== On June 19, 2018, 38 [[United Nations]] member states released a collective statement through the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC), calling on the Republic of the Philippines and Philippine president [[Rodrigo Duterte]] to stop the killings in the country and probe abuses caused by the deadly drug war. The 38 nations included [[Australia]], [[Austria]], [[Belgium]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Canada]], [[Croatia]], [[Cyprus]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Denmark]], [[Estonia]], [[Finland]], [[France]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Germany]], [[Greece]], [[Iceland]], [[Ireland]], [[Italy]], [[Latvia]], [[Liechtenstein]], [[Lithuania]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Malta]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]], [[Montenegro]], the [[Netherlands]], [[New Zealand]], [[Poland]], [[Portugal]], [[Romania]], [[Slovakia]], [[Slovenia]], [[Spain]], [[Sweden]], [[Switzerland]], [[Ukraine]], the [[United Kingdom]] and the [[United States]].{{cite web|url=https://globalnation.inquirer.net/168095/38-nations-ask-ph-stop-killings-probe-abuses|title=38 nations ask PH: Stop killings, probe abuses|first=Philippine Daily|last=Inquirer|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://thestandard.com.ph/news/top-stories/268837/38-nations-seek-end-to-killings-.html|title=38 nations seek end to 'killings'|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/205635-iceland-joint-statement-human-rights-council-philippines-killings|title=Iceland, 37 countries to Philippines: Let U.N. probe killings|publisher=}} ==In popular media== ===Television=== On April 9, 2018, Netflix aired its first series from the Philippines entitled, AMO, made by Filipino director, Brillante Mendoza.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/digital/asia/netflix-brillante-mendoza-amo-philippines-1202733499/|title=Netflix Picks Brillante Mendoza Drug War Show ‘AMO’ as First Philippines Series|first=Patrick|last=Frater|date=22 March 2018|publisher=}} ===Music=== "Hustisya" is a rap song about the drug war which was created by local artists inspired by the death of their friend immortalized in a photograph often compared to Michelangelo's ''[[Pietà (Michelangelo)|Pieta]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/08/asia/philippines-duterte-michael-siaron-one-pro-exclusive-tribute/index.html|title='Is this the new Filipino life?' Manila rappers blast Duterte's war on drugs|first=Euan McKirdy|last=CNN|website=CNN}} In December 2016, American singer [[James Taylor]] posted on social media that he had cancelled his concert in Manila, which was set for February 2017, citing the increasing number of deaths related to the drug war.{{cite news|title=James Taylor cancels Manila show, cites drug war|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/12/21/16/james-taylor-cancels-manila-show-cites-drug-war|work=ABS-CBN News}}{{cite news|title=Promoter speaks up on cancelled James Taylor show|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/12/22/16/promoter-speaks-up-on-cancelled-james-taylor-show|work=ABS-CBN News}} ===Photography=== On April 11, 2017, ''The New York Times'' won a [[Pulitzer Prize]] for breaking news photography on their Philippine Drug war report. The story was published on December 7, 2016, and was titled "''They Are Slaughtering Us Like Animals''".{{cite web|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/04/11/NYT-Pulitzer-Prize-PH-drug-war-report.html|title=NYT wins Pulitzer Prize for PH drug war report|publisher=[[CNN Philippines]]|accessdate=11 April 2017}} The ''La Pieta''{{cite news|last1=Phippen|first1=J. Weston|title=Can This Photo End Vigilante Killings in the Philippines?|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/news/archive/2016/08/la-pieta-philippines-duterte/494330/|accessdate=22 December 2017|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=6 August 2016}} or the "Philippines ''Pieta''", named after the [[Pietà (Michelangelo)|sculpture by Michelangelo]], refers to the photograph of Jennilyn Olayres holding the lifeless corpse of Michael Siaron, who was shot dead by unidentified assailants in [[Pasay]], [[Metro Manila]], on July 23, 2016. The image was widely used in the national press.{{cite news|title='Is this the new Filipino life?' Manila rappers blast Duterte's war on drugs|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/03/08/asia/philippines-duterte-michael-siaron-one-pro-exclusive-tribute/index.html|work=[[CNN]]}} The death of Michael Siaron remains unsolved for almost a year. [[Malacañang Palace|Malacañang]] asserts that the man behind the killing were committed by drug syndicates themselves.{{cite news|title=Slay of ‘Pieta’ drug suspect Michael Siaron proves drug traders kill each other —Palace|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/metro/630362/slay-of-pieta-drug-suspect-michael-siaron-proves-drug-traders-kill-each-other-palace/story/|work=GMA News}} After Siaron was shot dead by unidentified assailants, a writing on a cardboard states, "Wag tularan si Siaron dahil pusher umano," was placed on his body. One year and three months after he was killed, the police identified as the suspected assailant as Nesty Santiago through a ballistic exam on the recovered firearm.{{cite news|title=PNP declares death linked to 'Pieta-like' photo solved|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/metro/630313/pnp-declares-death-linked-to-pieta-like-photo-solved/story/|issue=GMA News}} Santiago was apparently a member of a syndicate involved in robberies, car thefts, hired killings and illegal drugs. The Pasay City Police declared his death as "case closed". However, Santiago was also killed by [[Snatch theft#Philippines|riding-in-tandem]] on December 29, 2016. No further investigation were made. A photo of a body of an alleged drug dealer, killed during a police anti-drug operation, in Manila by Noel Celis has been selected as one of [[Time Magazine|Time Magazine's]] top 100 photos of 2017.{{cite web|url=http://time.com/top-100-photos-of-2017/|title=TIME's Top 100 Photos of 2017|publisher=}} ===Mobile gaming=== There are various mobile games featuring Duterte fighting criminals,{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2017/10/12/duterte-apple-war-on-drugs-game.amp|title=People are petitioning for Apple to take down games glorifying Duterte's war on drugs|first=Yvette|last=Tan|publisher=|accessdate=19 November 2017}} many of which have since been censored by [[Apple Inc.]] from their [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]] following an appeal by various regional organizations.{{cite news|last1=Mateo|first1=Janvic|last2=Tupas|first2=Emmanuel|title=Apple takes down Tokhang mobile games|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/11/29/1763516/apple-takes-down-tokhang-mobile-games|accessdate=29 November 2017|work=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=29 November 2017}} ==See also== *[[Mega Drug Treatment and Rehabilitation Center]] *[[War on Drugs]] *[[Mexican Drug War]] *[[Human rights in Thailand#Deaths relating to the 2003 war on drugs]] *[[Illegal drug trade in the Philippines]] *[[Comprehensive Dangerous Drugs Act of 2002]] *[[2017 Bureau of Customs drug smuggling scandal]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/794598/kill-list-drugs-duterte The Kill List] – published by the ''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]'' in an attempt to document the casualties of the Philippine Drug War. *[http://www.rappler.com/nation/142210-duterte-list-lgu-police-officials-linked-drugs The Duterte list: Judges, mayors, police officials linked to drugs] - The [[Negrito]] peoples of the Philippines speak various [[Philippine languages]]. They have more in common with neighboring languages than with each other,<ref name="Lobel2013"/> and are listed here merely as an aid to identification.

Manoa: University of Hawai'i at Manoa.</ref> lists the following Black Filipino (i.e., Philippine Negrito) ethnolinguistic groups.

"Possible Non-Austronesian Lexical Elements in Philippine Negrito Languages." Other Southeast Asian languages with high proportions of unique vocabulary of possible isolate origin include the [[Enggano language]] of Indonesia and the [[Kenaboi language]] of Malaysia.
