{{EngvarB|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Other uses|2020 Vision (disambiguation)}} '''''Wawasan 2020''''' ([[Jawi alphabet|Jawi]]: واوسن ٢٠٢٠) or '''Vision 2020''' is a [[Malaysia]]n [[Ideal (ethics)|ideal]] introduced by the current [[Prime Minister of Malaysia]], [[Mahathir Mohamad]] during the tabling of the [[Sixth Malaysia Plan]] in 1991. The vision calls for the nation to achieve a self-sufficient industrialised nation by the year 2020, encompasses all aspects of life, from economic prosperity, social well-being, educational worldclass, political stability, as well as psychological balance. To achieve Vision 2020, Mahathir lamented that the nation required an annual growth of 7% (in real terms) over the thirty-year period 1990–2020, so that the economy would be eightfold stronger than its 1990 [[Gross Domestic Product|GDP]] of RM115 billion. This would translate to a GDP of RM920 billion (in 1990 [[Malaysian Ringgit|Ringgit]] terms) in 2020.<ref name="Mahathir's Speech">{{cite web|url=http://www.pmo.gov.my/?menu=page&page=1904|title=The Way Forward|author=[[Mahathir Mohamad]]|publisher=Prime Minister’s Office|date=17 November 2008|accessdate=14 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203071129/http://www.pmo.gov.my/?menu=page&page=1904|archivedate=3 December 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="Ibrahim, 2007">Jeong Chun Hai @ Ibrahim, & Nor Fadzlina Nawi. (2007). Principles of Public Administration. Kuala Lumpur: Karisma Publications. Also see, Jeong Chun Hai. (2007). Fundamental of Development Administration. Selangor: Scholar Press. Also see, Mohamed Jawhar Hassan. (1995). 'Malaysia in 1994: Staying in Course.' Asian Survey, Vol.35, No.2, A Survey of Asia in 1994: Part II (Feb. 1995), 186–193.</ref>. Under Vision 2020 from 1991 to 2020, there are 3 sub 10 year development policy namely National development Policy 1991-2000 with OPP2, National Vision Policy 2001-2010 with OPP3 and New Economic Model 2011-2020 with National Transformation Programme NTP.
''Wawasan 2020'' is also the title of an article by [[William Greider]] about [[globalisation]] in Malaysia.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Frank J. Lechner|author2=John Boli|title=The Globalization Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1fkMaiBC3NYC&pg=RA1-PA160|date=8 December 2003|publisher=Wiley|isbn=978-1-4051-0280-3|pages=1–}}</ref>
== Challenges == Mahathir outlined nine strategic challenges that Malaysia must overcome to achieve Vision 2020.<ref name="Mahathir's Speech"/><ref name="Ibrahim, 2007"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epu.gov.my/184|title=Vision 2020, 1991-2020|publisher= Economic Planning Unit|date=14 January 2008|accessdate=14 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090708144022/http://www.epu.gov.my/184|archivedate=8 July 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref> * Challenge 1: Establishing a united Malaysian nation made up of one Bangsa Malaysia (Malaysian Race). * Challenge 2: Creating a psychologically liberated, secure and developed Malaysian society. * Challenge 3: Fostering and developing a mature democratic society. * Challenge 4: Establishing a fully moral and ethical society. * Challenge 5: Establishing a matured liberal and tolerant society. * Challenge 6: Establishing a scientific and progressive society. * Challenge 7: Establishing a fully caring society. * Challenge 8: Ensuring an economically just society, in which there is a fair and equitable distribution of the wealth of the nation. * Challenge 9: Establishing a prosperous society with an economy that is fully competitive, dynamic, robust and resilient.
== Song == Wawasan 2020 is also a patriotic song on the same idea sung in [[Malay language|Malay]]. The song was composed by Akbar Nawab.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctl.utm.my/merdeka/calon/merdeka24/wawasan.html|title=Wawasan 2020 Song Lyrics|author=Akbar Nawab|publisher=[[Universiti Teknologi Malaysia]]|accessdate=14 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224181823/http://www.ctl.utm.my/merdeka/calon/merdeka24/wawasan.html|archivedate=24 February 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
== Revisions to the vision == In view of changing global conditions amid the [[financial crisis of 2007–2010]], Ex Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]] had in August 2009, said that there was now a need to redefine and recalibrate the vision in terms of how to achieve it, as well as its timeline. Najib, who said that it was necessary for Malaysia to undertake bold [[economic reform]]s, had tasked the National Economic Advisory Council (NEAC) to carry out a review of the vision. The NEAC is expected to publish its report by end 2009, with a second report on implementation 6 months after that. Najib also said that in order for Malaysia to achieve a developed nation status by 2020, the country has to grow at an annual rate of 8% over the next 10 years. He cited that a lower hypothetical growth of 6% per annum would delay Malaysia's vision to become a [[developed country]] by 10 years to 2030. Malaysia’s GDP growth rate averaged 7.2% per annum in the 1990s, and slowed to 5.4% per annum in the following decade.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.btimes.com.my/Current_News/BTIMES/articles/plussy2-2/Article/|title=8pc yearly growth vital to achieve developed nation status: Najib|author=Adeline Paul Raj|publisher=Business Times|date=29 August 2009|accessdate=14 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090829172714/http://www.btimes.com.my/Current_News/BTIMES/articles/plussy2-2/Article/|archivedate=29 August 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601068&sid=aAvHYIgq46lg&FORM=ZZNR8|title=Malaysia Must Expand Faster to Be Developed Nation, Najib Says|author1=Ranjeetha Pakiam|author2=Shamim Adam|publisher=Bloomberg|date=28 August 2009|accessdate=14 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119020236/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aAvHYIgq46lg&FORM=ZZNR8|archivedate=19 November 2015|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v5/news_lite.php?id=436342|title=Malaysia Must Grow 8 Percent Annually To Achieve Developed Nation Status, Says PM|publisher=Bernama|date=28 August 2009|accessdate=14 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604031958/http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v5/news_lite.php?id=436342|archivedate=4 June 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/36250-pm-grow-by-8pc-or-malaysia-will-not-achieve-vision-2020|title=PM: Grow by 8pc or Malaysia will not achieve Vision 2020|author=Adip Zalkapli|publisher=The Malaysian Insider|date=28 August 2009|accessdate=14 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090829215304/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/36250-pm-grow-by-8pc-or-malaysia-will-not-achieve-vision-2020|archivedate=29 August 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
In 2018, Najib Razak launched the National Transformation 2050 (TN50), where by 2050 Malaysia will be "a nation of calibre, with a new mindset".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/tn50-what-youths-want-for-malaysia|title=TN50: What youths want for Malaysia|publisher=The Malay Mail|date=28 February 2018|accessdate=14 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiandigest.com/frontpage/282-main-tile/725525-tn50-is-malaysia-s-dream.html|title=TN50 Is Malaysia's Dream|work=New Straits Times|publisher=Malaysian Digest|date=28 February 2018|accessdate=14 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/10/182377/pm-najib-announces-tn50-new-30-year-vision-malaysia|title=PM Najib announces TN50, a new 30-year vision for Malaysia|publisher=New Straits Times|date=21 October 2016|accessdate=14 March 2018}}</ref>
== References and sources == <references />
== External links == * [http://www.wawasan2020.com/vision/index.html Wawasan 2020 website] * [http://www.pmo.gov.my Malaysia Prime Minister’s Office] * [http://www.epu.gov.my Malaysia Economic Planning Unit website] * [http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=2518397899479618436 Google Video], Mahathir's speech. * [http://www.rtm.net.my/radio/html_bi/patriotic.html Wawasan 2020 song], The Wawasan 2020 audio file on RTM's radio site.

Samantha Schnee, Founding Editor| | founded = 2003 | firstdate = July–August 2003 | company = | country = | based = | language = English | website = {{URL|http://wordswithoutborders.org}} | issn = 1936-1459 | oclc = }} '''''Words Without Borders''''' ('''''WWB''''') is an international [[magazine]] opened to international exchange through [[translation]], publication, and promotion of the world’s best writing and authors who are not easily accessible to English-speaking readers. ==Translation and knowledge== ''Words without Borders'' promotes cultural understanding through the translation, publication, and promotion of the finest contemporary international literature. It publishes a monthly magazine of literature in translation and organizes special events that connect foreign writers to the public; it also develops materials for high school and college teachers and provides an online resource center for contemporary global writing.[http://www.wordswithoutborders.org/about About WWB] Words without Borders is supported by the [[National Endowment for the Arts]], the [[New York State Council on the Arts]] and the Lannan Foundation, among others. Words without Borders was founded by Alane Salierno Mason, translator of [[Elio Vittorini]],[[Elio Vittorini]], ''Conversations in Sicily (Conversazione in Sicilia),'' intr. by [[Ernest Hemingway]], trans. Alane Salierno Mason, [[Canongate Books]], 2003 ({{ISBN|1841954500}}). in 1999[http://bigthink.com/alanesaliernomason/alane-salierno-mason-introduces-words-without-borders/ Alane Salierno Mason Introduces Words without Borders] on ''bigthink.com'' and began publication in 2003. David Orr, in ''[[The New York Times]]'', compliments the "intelligence and idealism" of WWB.David Orr, ''The Widening Web of Digital Lit'', ''New York Times Book Review'', 2004. ==See also== * [[American Literary Translators Association]] * [[International Federation of Translators]] * [[Without Borders]] ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.wordswithoutborders.org/}} *{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A05E5DE153DF93BA25751C0A9629C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all|title=Online Magazine Removes Cultural Blinders|last=Salamon|first=Julie|authorlink=Julie Salamon|date=February 18, 2004|work=[[The New York Times]]}} [[Category:Communication]] [[Category:Literary translation magazines]] [[Category:Literary translation websites]] [[Category:American online magazines]] [[Category:American literary magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 2003]] [[Category:American monthly magazines]] [[Category:Magazines published in New York City]] [[Category:2003 establishments in New York (state)]]
